title: How to tell if the water is soft or hard - Quora

response.answer_text: 1. Are You Noticing a Lot of Soap Scum? Soap scum is another stain hard water’s notorious for. These come in the form of white spots, usually found in the shower or on your dishes. These stains are the result of water evaporating, leaving calcium residue behind. Yuck! 2. Showers Are No Longer Relaxing Unfortunately, the minerals found in hard water don’t react well with soap. This can make it difficult to get a good lather when you shower. Plus, hard water often leaves limescale on your shower head which reduces water pressure. 3. Are Your Clothes Fading? The magnesium and calcium found in hard water doesn’t react well to laundry detergent, either. Consequently, your clothes will feel harder and colors will begin to fade with every wash because it’s difficult for the washing machine to wash away all the soap. It’s proven that hard water makes your clothes wear out faster and can make towels feel rough. 4. Is Your Family Suffering from Skin Irritation? Hard water can take its toll on sensitive skin. This is because when you clean yourself with hard water, it’s often difficult to wash all the soap away. When this residue is left, it can irritate the skin and cause it to dry out. 5. Are Your Appliances Breaking? This is the most expensive issue. Limescale can cause home appliances to deteriorate rapidly. We’re referring to everything from the kettle to the dishwasher. This buildup also makes your appliance less efficient which means needlessly expensive utility bills. For more information on hard water and how to fix it visit: 5 Signs You Have Hard Water and What to Do About It | Kinetico CGC

· Hard water effects cannot hide. It shows off by itself easily. White encrusted layers in pipes and faucets, clogged shower heads, ugly stains in sinks and bathtubs and scaled bathroom tiles are signs of hard water. Hard water leaves behind white spots on glassware and dishes. · An easy test to identify if your water is “hard” is the soap test. Soap and detergent lather less in hard water. The mineral ions in hard water act against the surfactant property of soap and reduce sud formation. · If you are using the City’s Municipal water supply, they will be able to provide you information on the hardness level of the water supplied to your house. You could also get the Total Dissolved Solids of the water in your house tested. For reference, you could contact 3M Water solutions on toll- free 1800-425-425000 to get the TDS in your water tested and recommended solutions.

Well, before answering your question, I would love you ask a few questions Do you find that your clothes look dingy, yellowish or greyish,Do you feel the fabric feels scratchy and uncomfortableDo you find white spots on glasses and dishes after you wash itDo you find scaly buildups on basins and tubsDo you find the pipeline gets clogged with the sediment and scale?If all these answers are yes, then you can say that the water that is supplied to your home is hard. Get a small bar of ordinary soap, can you wash your hands and create a good lather? If not you have hard water. It does not matter much you only have to use more soap, modern nonionic detergents are not affected by hardness anyway.Make a telephone call to your water company ( or check their website ) to find out exactly how hard or soft your water supply is.
